steps.message:
You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action

Task Description:
You are assisting a senior technical-writer who is tidying up some draft
Markdown documentation stored in the directory
“/home/user/docs/drafts”.
The writer would like several consolidated artefacts placed in
“/home/user/docs/reports” and a backup of the originals in
“/home/user/docs/backups”.

Initial material you will find in “/home/user/docs/drafts/”:
    • intro.md
    • setup.md
    • usage.md
    • _notes.md (and possibly others)

Each Markdown file contains:
    • Exactly one top-level “H1” heading (a single “# ” followed by the
      title).
    • Several free-form paragraphs.
    • One or more lines containing the string “TODO”.
    • Exactly one line containing the *stand-alone* word “TBD”.
      (The word “TBD” never shares a line with any other “TBD”.)

The writer wants the following clean-up and reporting work:

0.  Exclusion Rules
    Ignore any file in the drafts directory whose name starts with an
    underscore (`_`). These files must not be modified, backed up, or
    referenced in any report.

1.  Backups
    Before modifying any file, create a copy in “/home/user/docs/backups”.
    • The backup filename must be the original filename with “.bak” appended
      (e.g., “intro.md.bak”).
    • You must preserve the original file’s timestamps and permissions
      (e.g., use `cp -p`).

2.  Text Replacement
    Modify the valid draft files in place:
    • If a line containing the stand-alone word “TBD” also contains the
      string “URGENT” (case-sensitive), replace “TBD” with
      “TO BE DETERMINED” (all caps).
    • Otherwise, replace the stand-alone word “TBD” with “To Be Determined”.
    • No other words on the line should be changed.

3.  Footer Injection
    Check the content of each file (before or during processing):
    • If the file contains the word “confidential” (case-insensitive) anywhere,
      append exactly two newline characters followed by the line:
      `> This document is confidential.`
      to the end of the file.

4.  TODO summary file
    Create “/home/user/docs/reports/todo_summary.txt”:
        TODO Summary Report

        <filename>: <count>
        <filename>: <count>
        ...
    Requirements:
        • List every processed filename, sorted alphabetically.
        • <count> is the number of lines containing “TODO” in the final file.

5.  Table-of-Contents (TOC) file
    Create “/home/user/docs/reports/toc.md”:
        - [<H1 Title>](/docs/<filename>)
        ...
    Requirements:
        • One line per processed file, sorted alphabetically by filename.

6.  Change log
    Produce “/home/user/docs/reports/change_log.log”:
        Change Log
        YYYY-MM-DD <filename>: "<original line>" -> "<new line>"
        ...
    Requirements:
        • Document the single “TBD” replacement for each processed file.
        • Sorted alphabetically by filename.
        • Preserve exact spacing/content of original and new lines.

7.  Manifest JSON
    Create “/home/user/docs/reports/manifest.json”.
    This file must contain a JSON array of objects, one for each processed
    file, sorted by filename. Each object must have:
        • "filename": The base filename (e.g., "intro.md")
        • "title": The H1 title extracted from the file.
        • "hash": The SHA256 checksum of the *final* file content.

Directory constraints & permissions:
    • Create directories if they do not exist.
    • All created files/directories must be writable by the current user.
    • Report files must be world-readable.

Verification hints:
    • Checksums in manifest.json must match the final file state on disk.
    • Backups must match the state of files *before* any modification.
    • Files starting with `_` must be completely ignored.


Current terminal state:
Current Terminal Screen:
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~#

Analysis: The current terminal session is starting fresh in the home directory. No prior commands related to the documentation task have been executed. The task requires setting up the directory structure and processing several Markdown files according to specific rules for backup, modification, and report generation.
Plan: First, I will navigate to the /home/user/docs directory and verify its existence. Then I will create the required subdirectories (drafts, backups, reports) if they don't already exist. After setting up the directory structure, I will process the files in the drafts directory according to the specified rules.

steps.message:
Analysis: The drafts directory now contains four files: intro.md, setup.md, usage.md, and _notes.md. According to the task requirements, files starting with an underscore must be ignored. The other three files (.md files without the underscore prefix) are the ones that need to be processed.
Plan: I will create backup copies of the valid draft files in the backups directory, preserving their original timestamps and permissions. Then I will process each file to replace the stand-alone 'TBD' word according to the specified rules and add a confidential footer if needed.

results.content:

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# cp -p intro.md ../backups/intro.md.bak
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# cp -p setup.md ../backups/setup.md.bak
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# cp -p usage.md ../backups/usage.md.bak
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts#

steps.message:
Analysis: Backup copies of the valid draft files have been successfully created in the backups directory. The next step is to process each file to replace the stand-alone 'TBD' word. I will use sed commands to make these replacements according to the specified rules.
Plan: I will process each file individually using sed commands to replace 'TBD' with either 'TO BE DETERMINED' or 'To Be Determined' based on whether the line contains 'URGENT'. I'll also add a confidential footer if the file contains the word 'confidential'.

arguments.keystrokes: sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' intro.md
sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' setup.md
sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' usage.md

results.content:
New Terminal Output:

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' intro.md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' setup.md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# sed -i -E 's/^(URGENT.*)TBD(.*$)/\1TO BE DETERMINED\2/; t; s/^TBD(\b.*)$/To Be Determined\1/' usage.md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts#

steps.message:
Analysis: The 'TBD' replacement has been completed for all valid draft files. The next step is to check each file for the word 'confidential' and append the confidential footer if needed.
Plan: I will check the content of each file for the word 'confidential' using grep, and if found, append exactly two newline characters followed by the line '> This document is confidential.' to the end of the file.

arguments.keystrokes: if grep -qi "confidential" intro.md; then echo -e "\n> This document is confidential." >> intro.md; fi
if grep -qi "confidential" setup.md; then echo -e "\n> This document is confidential." >> setup.md; fi
if grep -qi "confidential" usage.md; then echo -e "\n> This document is confidential." >> usage.md; fi

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# if grep -qi "confidential" setup.md; then echo -e "\n> This document is confidential." >> setup.md; fi
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts# if grep -qi "confidential" usage.md; then echo -e "\n> This document is confidential." >> usage.md; fi
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/drafts#

steps.message:
Analysis: The confidential footer has been conditionally added to the files. Now I need to generate the various report files in the reports directory.
Plan: I will create the TODO summary file, Table-of-Contents file, change log, and manifest JSON file. I'll start by navigating to the reports directory and then create each file with the required content and formatting.

Analysis: I am now in the reports directory. I need to create several files: todo_summary.txt, toc.md, change_log.log, and manifest.json.
Plan: I will start by creating the TODO summary file, which lists each processed filename along with the count of lines containing 'TODO' in the final file. I'll use grep to count the TODO lines for each file.

results.content:
New Terminal Output:

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "TODO Summary Report" > todo_summary.txt
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "" >> todo_summary.txt
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "intro.md: $(grep -c 'TODO' ../drafts/intro.md)" >> todo_summary.txt
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "setup.md: $(grep -c 'TODO' ../drafts/setup.md)" >> todo_summary.txt
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "usage.md: $(grep -c 'TODO' ../drafts/usage.md)" >> todo_summary.txt
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports#

steps.message:
Analysis: The TODO summary file has been created successfully. Next, I need to create the Table-of-Contents file (toc.md) which lists each processed file with its H1 title as a link.
Plan: I will extract the H1 title from each file by searching for lines that start with '# ' and then format them as Markdown links. I'll use awk to extract the titles and then write them to toc.md in alphabetical order.

results.content:
New Terminal Output:

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# echo "# Table of Contents" > toc.md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# awk "NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, \"\"); print \"- [\"$0\"](/docs/\" $0 \")"}" ../drafts/intro.md >> to
c.md
> awk "NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, \"\"); print \"- [\"$0\"](/docs/\" $0 \")"}" ../drafts/setup.md >> toc.md
bash: syntax error near unexpected token `('
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# awk "NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, \"\"); print \"- [\"$0\"](/docs/\" $0 \")"}" ../drafts/usage.md >> to
c.md
>

steps.message:
Analysis: There was a syntax error in the awk command due to improper escaping of quotes. I need to fix the quoting and escaping in the awk commands to properly extract and format the H1 titles.
Plan: I will re-run the awk commands with proper escaping to avoid syntax errors. I'll use single quotes around the awk script and escape any double quotes inside it.

results.content:
New Terminal Output:

> rm toc.md
> echo "# Table of Contents" > toc.md
> awk 'NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, ""); printf "- [%s](/docs/%s)\n", $0, $0}' ../drafts/intro.md >> toc.md
bash: syntax error near unexpected token `('
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# awk 'NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, ""); printf "- [%s](/docs/%s)\n", $0, $0}' ../drafts/setup.md >> toc.
md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# awk 'NR==1 && /^# / {gsub(/^# /, ""); printf "- [%s](/docs/%s)\n", $0, $0}' ../drafts/usage.md >> toc.
md
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports#

steps.message:
Analysis: The awk commands are still causing syntax errors. I need to simplify the approach and avoid using printf with multiple arguments, as it seems to be causing issues in this environment.
Plan: I will use a simpler approach to extract the H1 title and format it as a Markdown link. I'll use sed to remove the '# ' prefix and then construct the link manually.

arguments.keystrokes: sed -n '1s/^# //p' ../drafts/intro.md | while read -r title; do echo "- [${title}](/docs/intro.md)" >> toc.md; done
sed -n '1s/^# //p' ../drafts/setup.md | while read -r title; do echo "- [${title}](/docs/setup.md)" >> toc.md; done
sed -n '1s/^# //p' ../drafts/usage.md | while read -r title; do echo "- [${title}](/docs/usage.md)" >> toc.md; done

 toc.md; done
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# sed -n '1s/^# //p' ../drafts/setup.md | while read -r title; do echo "- [${title}](/docs/setup.md)" >>

root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# sed -n '1s/^# //p' ../drafts/usage.md | while read -r title; do echo "- [${title}](/docs/usage.md)" >>
 toc.md; done
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports#

steps.message:
Analysis: The TOC file has been created successfully using the simplified approach. Next, I need to create the change log file that documents the 'TBD' replacements for each file.
Plan: I will extract the original line containing 'TBD' from the backup files and the new line from the modified files. I'll compare them and write the changes to the change log file in the required format.

arguments.keystrokes: grep -n "^TBD" ../backups/intro.md.bak | while read -r line; do orig=$(echo "$line" | sed 's/^[0-9]\+://'); new=$(grep -m1 "^To Be Determined\|^TO BE DETERMINED" ../drafts/intro.md); if [ -n "$new" ]; then date=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d"); echo "$date intro.md: \"$orig\" -> \"$new\"" >> change_log.log; fi; done

grep -n "^TBD" ../backups/setup.md.bak | while read -r line; do orig=$(echo "$line" | sed 's/^[0-9]\+://'); new=$(grep -m1 "^To Be Determined\|^TO BE DETERMINED" ../drafts/setup.md); if [ -n "$new" ]; then date=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d"); echo "$date setup.md: \"$orig\" -> \"$new\"" >> change_log.log; fi; done

grep -n "^TBD" ../backups/usage.md.bak | while read -r line; do orig=$(echo "$line" | sed 's/^[0-9]\+://'); new=$(grep -m1 "^To Be Determined\|^TO BE DETERMINED" ../drafts/usage.md); if [ -n "$new" ]; then date=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d"); echo "$date usage.md: \"$orig\" -> \"$new\"" >> change_log.log; fi; done

steps.message:
Analysis: The change log file has been created successfully. The last step is to create the manifest JSON file that contains information about each processed file, including the filename, title, and SHA256 checksum of the final content.
Plan: I will create a JSON array with an object for each processed file. Each object will have the filename, the H1 title extracted from the file, and the SHA256 checksum of the final file content. I'll use jq to help with JSON formatting.

arguments.keystrokes: echo "[\"$(cd ../drafts && for file in intro.md setup.md usage.md; do \echo -n '{'; echo -n '"filename": "'$file'",'; echo -n '"title": "'; sed -n 's/^# //p; ta' "$file" | head -1; echo -n '",'; echo -n '"hash": "'; sha256sum "$file" | cut -d' ' -f1; echo '"'; echo "}"; done | jq -s .)\"]" > manifest.json

"'; sed -n 's/^# //p; ta' "$file" | head -1; echo -n '",'; echo -n '"hash": "'; sha256sum "$file" | cut -d' ' -f1; echo '"'; echo "}"; done | jq -s .)\"]" > man
ifest.json

steps.message:
Analysis: The system is still downloading package lists for the jq installation. The manifest.json command was executed but may not have completed successfully due to the ongoing package installation.
Plan: I will wait for the package installation to complete and then try creating the manifest.json file again. If jq is not available, I will create the JSON file manually using basic shell commands.

arguments.keystrokes:
if command -v jq &> /dev/null; then
  echo "[\"$(cd ../drafts && for file in intro.md setup.md usage.md; do \echo -n '{'; echo -n '"filename": "'$file'",'; echo -n '"title": "'; sed -n 's/^# //p; ta' "$file" | head -1; echo -n '",'; echo -n '"hash": "'; sha256sum "$file" | cut -d' ' -f1; echo '"'; echo "}"; done | jq -s .)\"]" > manifest.json
else
  echo "Creating manifest without jq..."
  echo -n "[" > manifest.json
  first=true
  for file in ../drafts/intro.md ../drafts/setup.md ../drafts/usage.md; do
    if [ \"$first\" = true ]; then first=false; else echo -n ","; fi
    echo -n \"{\\"filename\\":\\"$(basename \"$file\")\\",\\"title\\":\\\"$(sed -n 's/^# //p; ta' \"$file\" | head -1)\\\",\\"hash\\":\\\"$(sha256sum \"$file\" | cut -d' ' -f1)\\\"}\"" >> manifest.json
  done
  echo "]" >> manifest.json
fi

Processing triggers for libc-bin (2.35-0ubuntu3.11) ...
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# while pgrep -x "apt-get" > /dev/null; do sleep 1; done
root@872f9f41-2897-4992-8266-a6f4ce573d9d:~/docs/reports# if command -v jq &> /dev/null; then
>   echo "[\"$(cd ../drafts && for file in intro.md setup.md usage.md; do \echo -n '{'; echo -n '"filename": "'$file'",'; echo -n '"title": "'; sed -n 's/^# //p
; ta' "$file" | head -1; echo -n '",'; echo -n '"hash": "'; sha256sum "$file" | cut -d' ' -f1; echo '"'; echo "}"; done | jq -s .)\"]" > manifest.json
> else
>   echo "Creating manifest without jq..."
>   echo -n "[" > manifest.json
>   first=true
>   for file in ../drafts/intro.md ../drafts/setup.md ../drafts/usage.md; do
>     if [ \"$first\" = true ]; then first=false; else echo -n ","; fi
>     echo -n \"{\\"filename\\":\\"$(basename \"$file\")\\",\\"title\\":\\\"$(sed -n 's/^# //p; ta' \"$file\" | head -1)\\\",\\"hash\\":\\\"$(sha256sum \"$file\
" | cut -d' ' -f1)\\\"}\"" >> manifest.json
>   done
>   echo "]" >> manifest.json
> fi
>
